question: Recent research suggests that the majority of criminals who are sent to prison commit crimes after they are released.Why is this the case?What can be done to solve this problem?
text: Many worldwide studies have pointed out that most of the lawbreakers, who are sent to prison, are likely to re-commit the crimes after being released. This article would shed light on several factors behind this phenomenon and point out appropriate solutions.

To begin with, criminals tend to re-break the laws after being released from prison because of several reasons. Firstly, the prison punishment for major crimes such as rapists, murders, homicide is not strict enough for criminals to be fully aware of their heinous actions. Secondly, the reaction of the community to the ex-prisoners integration attempts is sometimes irrelevant. For example, companies hardly intentionally hire ex-offenders. The communities usually bear animosity towards people who have served in prison.  As a result, the majority of criminals have to recommit crimes.

Actions must be taken as soon as possible to minimize the recommitment of breaking laws. First of all, the punishment for major crimes should be more appropriate than the present. By doing so, the offenders could gain more awareness about their actions.Therefore, they are likely to pose less chance to recommit the crimes.
